description: From Middle English estat, from Anglo-Norman estat and Old French estat (French: état), from Latin status. Doublet of state and status.

entries.meaning: The collective property and liabilities of someone, especially a deceased person. [from 19th c.]
(archaic) The condition of one's fortunes; prosperity, possessions. [from 14th c.]
(obsolete) A "person of estate"; a nobleman or noblewoman. [14th–17th c.]
examples: Herod on his birthday made a supper to his lords, high captains, and chief estates of Galilee.

entries.meaning: (historical) A major social class or order of persons regarded collectively as part of the body politic of the country and formerly possessing distinct political rights (Estates of the realm). [from 14th c.]
examples: I am afraid that some of the nobles who are campaigning for it simply want to use the Estates to cut down the King's power and increase their own.

entries.meaning: (law) The nature and extent of a person's interest in, or ownership of, land. [from 15th c.]
An (especially extensive) area of land, under a single ownership. [from 18th c.]
The landed property owned or controlled by a government or a department of government.
(UK, sometimes derogatory) A housing estate. [from 20th c.]

(UK, automotive) A station wagon; a car with a tailgate (or liftgate) and storage space to the rear of the seating which is coterminous with the passenger compartment (and often extensible into that compartment via folding or removable seating). [from 20th c.]
(obsolete) The state; the general body politic; the common-wealth; the general interest; state affairs.
examples: I call matter of estate not only the parts of sovereignty, but whatsoever […] concerneth manifestly any great portion of people.

entries.meaning: (computing) An organization's collective information technology resources.
examples: This time, however, it only includes the static parameters that you expect to be consistent across your estate.

verbs.description: estate (third-person singular simple present estates, present participle estating, simple past and past participle estated)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To give an estate to.
